The weighted average Price/Sales and EV/EBITDA were adjusted for the impact of outliers, with those multiples at over 100x. For the WA earnings yield, EYs for loss-making companies were removed.

Size And Value

  • With just three trillion-dollar companies in the portfolio (vs. nine in IVV), SIXG has a weighted average market cap about 2.4x smaller.
  • Despite that, its portfolio appears much more generously valued, as illustrated by its smaller adjusted WA earnings yield, as well as much higher adjusted WA Price/Sales and Enterprise Value/EBITDA. This creates meaningful risks investors should be prepared for.

Growth

SIXG has a stronger weighted average forward earnings growth rate, which partly explains why its EY is quite low (and translates into an almost 36x Price/Earnings) compared to IVV, plus more than half of its net assets are allocated to companies with a B- Quant Growth grade or higher. Still, the S&P 500 ETF is offering more appealing forward revenue and EBITDA growth rates.

Quality

Most of SIXG's holdings are high-quality companies with capital efficiency indicators and margins at quite healthy levels. However, IVV is considerably stronger here. For instance, it has a larger exposure to companies with a B- Quant Profitability grade or higher.

Low Volatility

SIXG is much more into high-beta stocks than IVV. The bull markets are a boon for high-beta names, as they tend to capture over 100% of the S&P 500 ETF's upside, delivering impressive gains. However, their losses in bear markets can be rather painful.

SIXG Risks

Like any other theme-focused ETF favoring growthier tech names, SIXG has two key risks.

High-Achiever Valuation Risk

Companies with strong growth prospects, lofty multiples, and high beta — exactly those that account for the bulk of the ETF's net assets — are extremely sensitive to periods of market stress. In other words, deterioration in macro conditions, including, for instance, too high inflation, can be detrimental for SIXG's performance, resulting in steep losses, with a good example being 2022 (back then, its maximum drawdown was 30.84%).

Theme Popularity Risk

There is a risk that the 5G/6G theme will become less and less popular with ETF investors, with asset flows switching to newer and more promising areas (i.e., pure-play AI-focused vehicles), even though the rise of the "AI connectivity" sub-theme might partly compensate for that.

Still, the fact is, SIXG saw some impressive inflows in the past, with AUM surpassing $1 billion in January 2021. However, it has dwindled since then.

So the issue is that the declining popularity of a theme and investors focusing on other more hyped trends are synonymous with declining assets under management, which first have an impact on an ETF's liquidity (hence, the ability to close a position quickly and at a desirable price), and then, if AUM drops too low, the prospect of a fund's liquidation arises.

SIXG Pros & Cons

Pros

  • SIXG offers a concentrated portfolio of the 5G and 6G players that, among other things, play an important role in the AI economy.
  • It holds numerous high achievers, not represented in both IVV and QQQ.
  • The ETF has confidently outperformed IVV and QQQ since the strategy change in 2024.
  • For a thematic ETF, its expense ratio is modest at 0.30%.
  • Compared to the subclass, its AUM is relatively large, while liquidity is comfortable.

Cons

  • The portfolio is high-priced and has a high beta, making it very vulnerable during periods of market stress.
  • Even in supportive conditions like those in 2024–2025, SIXG delivered a quite deep maximum drawdown (i.e., -13.36% vs. IVV's -7.43% over October 2024–September 2025).
  • Since 2021, the ETF has seen significant asset outflows despite solid performance, with the AUM now being just at around 48% of its 2021 peak.

SIXG Peer Comparison

SIXG has two main peers, namely the First Trust Indxx NextG ETF (NXTG) and the AXS Esoterica NextG Economy ETF (WUGI).

The table below provides a few key facts, with QQQ and IVV added to ensure an appropriate context.

  • While NXTG is the oldest in the peer group, its strategy was changed in May 2019 when it switched from the Nasdaq CTA Smartphone IndexSM to the Indxx 5G & NextG Thematic IndexSM.
  • In terms of AUM, SIXG is the largest in the peer group.
  • WUGI is the only one that is actively managed.
  • SIXG's expense ratio is the lowest compared to NXTG and WUGI.
  • The Defiance ETF has outperformed both WUGI and NXTG over October 2024–September 2025.

Bottom Line

  • The Defiance Connective Technologies ETF is a passively managed vehicle offering exposure to the "Next Generation of Connective Technologies."
  • Focused mainly on 5G and 6G tech, it holds numerous high achievers that are at the forefront of the cutting-edge tech development and implementation, like NVIDIA, Apple, Nokia, Marvell Technology, etc.
  • The ETF does deliver rather appealing performance in supportive conditions, with 2024 and 2025 being nothing short of robust thanks to the AI revolution narrative.
  • However, in thematic ETF investing, too much enthusiasm is very dangerous. In other words, it is worth keeping in mind that SIXG is highly volatile (2022 is to remember), and most of its holdings have high beta and are priced for perfection, which means that a shift in the market narrative from euphoria to depression can easily make its solid gains evaporate fast.

This article answers these three main questions about SIXG:

  • Should SIXG be viewed more as a satellite holding or a core position?
  • Is SIXG considered more volatile than the overall market?
  • How has SIXG performed compared to similar ETFs, as well as the overall market?

Editor's note: This article is intended to provide a general overview of the ETF for educational purposes only and, unlike other articles on Seeking Alpha, does not offer an investment opinion about the ETF.

data.title: Nvidia Is Untouchable For 2026
data.description:
NVIDIA Corporation (NVDA) continues to benefit from the global excitement around artificial intelligence, experiencing strong demand for its GPU and networking solutions. The strong data center build-out provides half a trillion dollars in revenue visibility, propelling the stock price more than 50% since the beginning of the year. Nvidia has crossed the $5 trillion valuation mark amidst the growing fears for the AI bubble. And while the bubble concerns were confirmed by some industry leaders, I believe that Nvidia is not associated with it. The company has the potential to grow at least at a 30% angle, while the valuation has climbed to its fair value since my previous coverage. Although the industry signals are strengthening with big tech’s approaching $100 billion in quarterly investments, my conservative growth scenario indicates 25% upside potential.

FY2026 is an Nvidia year

With the rapid proliferation of artificial intelligence in the recent year, Nvidia has experienced a surge in demand for its GPU solutions, allowing the company to showcase impressive rates of financial growth. The stock price is up by 50% since the beginning of the year, significantly outperforming the technology sector and the broad market.

NVDA is also up 92% since my previous writing, as the company rebounded significantly from the setback caused by export constraints on AI chips to China and the tariff policies. Since then, the solid data center investment pipeline has pushed NVDA to become the world’s most valuable company. Apart from that, the AI frenzy is fueling the market bubble fears due to the circular large-scale investments between the main AI players. And because of the long-term nature of the investment plans, there will always be skepticism about how many of those investments will break ground. In my view, the three-year horizon is quite a long-term period, as the dynamics of the trade disputes and geopolitical tensions cannot be really predicted.

However, let’s take a look at the current supply chain stance. TSMC projected mid-30% revenue growth due to the accelerating demand for AI and HPC chips from hyperscalers and AI-accelerator customers. The utilization of the leading-edge node is expected to be very high as the demand is surging. At the same time, the HBM supply is shaping up to be tight, with SK hynix Inc. (OTCPK:HXSCF) hinting at a sellout of its 2026 production capacity and AI-related demand squeezing out DDR5 capacity.

Another bottleneck spot is packaging, which is becoming increasingly important for the latest generation of AI chips. In addition, Amkor increased its total investments for the new advanced packaging and test campus in Arizona up to $7 billion. Going further, Vertiv Holdings Co (VRT) reported surging orders and a robust backlog due to the strong AI-driven demand for digital infrastructure solutions such as power management, cooling systems and integrated data center platforms. Overall, the demand is prominently outstripping supply, and Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) forecasts show a data center crunch persisting into 2026 as well.

But apart from the AI bubble, the competitive landscape is rising over. Besides the ASICs' collusions, Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. (AMD) is progressing to be the most fearful alternative with a full-stack Helios rack-scale AI platform, which is believed to be on par with Vera Rubin. Both systems feature 72 GPUs onboard and are expected to enter mass production in the back half of 2026. Now, let’s recall AMD’s $500 billion data center AI accelerator TAM estimate in 2028. The figure now seems more than viable given the fact that big tech is expected to dedicate more than $344 billion this year.

The capital investments are growing at an impressive pace, with quarterly Capex from Meta, Google, Amazon, and Microsoft approaching the $100 billion level combined. On the other hand, another forecast from Citi is pointing to $490 billion in AI Capex across the hyperscalers already in 2026 and a total of $2.8 trillion through 2029. And while I used to take the projections made by Nvidia’s executives with a grain of salt, the $3-4 trillion in AI infrastructure spending by the end of the decade seems reasonable.

But let’s stick to the $500 billion AI accelerator market size scenario, which is still a significant jump compared to some $130 billion in 2024. If we suppose that Nvidia would maintain around 60% market share, it suggests up to $300 billion in revenue from the data center segment in 2028, or circa 30% CAGR. Despite growing by 56% YoY in the second fiscal quarter of 2025, the company will come down to such a growth dynamic at some point.

Nonetheless, this projection is far more conservative compared to Jensen Huang’s visibility into half a trillion in sales for Grace Blackwell and Vera Rubin through 2026. This figure most likely includes the partnership with OpenAI (OPENAI) to deploy at least 10 gigawatts of Nvidia AI systems. Indeed, with the rollout of Blackwell Ultra systems, Nvidia is going to dominate the market in 2026 as well. However, we should discern the visibility from when this revenue is actually going to be recognized. And even if AMD comes up with a superior rack-scale platform, the point is that such a big market share is not going to dissipate any time soon. Because, as I wrote in my latest piece on AMD, the main advantage of Nvidia is in the timing between architectural generations. AMD opted for a new process technology for its MI350 series, which took time for the transition to the 3nm lithography.

On the other hand, Nvidia switched to a double-die package, effectively doubling the performance of the Hopper generation while staying at the same process node. Moreover, Nvidia is planning to shift its roadmap to only an eight-month gap in production ramp-up, which could be highly beneficial, especially when the market for AI systems continues to be supply chain-restricted.

Reversion angle

Against the backdrop of the AI bubble fears, it’s hard to believe that a company worth nearly $5 trillion with a 50% stock price gain since the beginning of the year is fairly valued. I used to mention that a 30% growth reversion angle could bring the valuation of NVDA stock down to the low 20x in FY2028. Apparently, it went so much faster due to the rapid expansion of data center build-outs. And looking at the chart now, the company is trading at 33.4x forward P/E, which is slightly below the 3-year median of 33.6x.

*The two dotted lines represent one standard deviation above and below the median line.

So, we can see that NVDA stock is clearly valued at its fair level, climbing from the bottom line of one standard deviation below the median from the time of my last piece. Basically, when you have a stock with the potential to grow at least by 30% and trading at a 30x multiple, it’s a good indication of a reasonable investment. I could confirm this with the following chart, which highlights that the earnings vector used moves in sync with the price performance dynamic.

Going forward, I prefer to stick with a 30% growth angle to form a more conservative scenario. I believe that NVDA stock has room for 30% multiple expansions for the next 12-month horizon, or up to 43x forward P/E ratio. Given the analyst forecast of $6.02 EPS next year, this indicates a $261 value per share, which stipulates a 25% upside potential.

Investment takeaways

With superior computing power and deep optimization, Nvidia accelerators deliver the world's highest performance for AI workloads, benefiting from the NVLink technology. Apart from that, the company develops high-performance networking (InfiniBand and Spectrum-X) solutions that enable the interconnection of large-scale clusters, which is especially relevant when we are talking about data center projects in gigawatt measure. The CUDA software stack is another strength, which has effectively become the industry standard, enabling the adaptation of GPUs to solve a wide range of computational tasks. These three pillars help Nvidia to retain customers in its ecosystem, due to the lack of meaningful substitution offerings, at least until the end of 2026.

Apart from that, Nvidia is continuously teaming up with industry leaders to ensure its technology remains at the forefront amid the AI revolution. The scope of investment into data center build-outs is constantly growing, representing a strong growth potential visibility. The demand signals make tech giants spend relentlessly on artificial intelligence, with Microsoft planning to double its data center footprint over the next 2 years, Meta signaling a strong Capex expansion, and Alphabet approaching $100 billion in investments for the year.

Hence, I believe that NVDA deserves a Buy recommendation even at a $5 trillion market cap. It remains to be seen how much of that revenue visibility mentioned at the GTC will even be recognized in the following five quarters. But definitely, Nvidia has the potential to grow at least by 30% in the near term, which, against the backdrop of a low 30s valuation multiple, looks like a good entry point. And even with a conservative expectation for TAM potential, NVDA stock still has 25% upside for the next 12-month horizon.

data.title: Toyota's Sixth-Gen RAV4 Symbolizes Electrification's Gradual Arrival
data.description:
Toyota Motor (TM) notched a significant milestone in 2024 when the RAV4 compact SUV, in its fifth generation, became the single best-selling vehicle model of any kind in the U.S., surpassing the Ford F150 pickup truck, a model that has dominated sales charts for decades.

The sixth-generation RAV4 soon will be available in U.S. Toyota dealerships, offering enhancements and features that likely will establish the model as a top seller for at least the near future. RAV4’s sales leadership in the U.S.—the world's most profitable vehicle market—is topping on the cake for the Japanese automaker, the No. 1 automaker worldwide in terms of unit sales.

According to the Toyota newsroom, prices for the new model will start in the low $30,000 range and rise to about $50,000 for the best-equipped versions.

The new RAV4—available only as a gas-electric hybrid or plug-in hybrid—exemplifies Toyota’s determination to electrify its product line gradually and along multiple pathways, rather than swiftly with battery electric vehicles (BEVs), a strategy that has drawn criticism from environmental activists and others who argue in favor of rapid migration to BEVs.

Toyota has argued that the limited worldwide capacity and resources for manufacturing batteries, inadequate charging infrastructure, and consumer hesitancy to switch to BEVs from internal combustion engines (especially in the U.S.) dictate a more deliberate and gradual move to BEVs over a longer period of time, perhaps many years. Ultimately, Toyota says, the overall reduction of so-called greenhouse gases will be greater under this strategy—while preserving the company’s financial health.

Meanwhile, automakers, including General Motors Co. (GM) and Ford Motor Co. (F), have booked massive losses, worker layoffs, and write-offs—with more to come—due to slow consumer acceptance of their first BEV models. Outside of China, where BEVs may be heavily subsidized and encouraged, automakers are now introducing BEVs more slowly.

Governments, too, are rethinking policies meant to incentivize BEVs.

Seamless technology

In truth, many buyers will be unaware that their 2026 RAV4 is powered by a combination of a gasoline engine and a battery-powered electric motor; the system smoothly and quietly (according to this writer’s experience during a test drive) produces an average fuel efficiency of up to 44 miles to the gallon, combined city and highway, according to Toyota’s estimate. The RAV4’s battery receives charge from the engine, meaning that it doesn’t need external charging.

A second RAV4 version, the plug-in hybrid, has a larger battery than the standard gas-electric and must be charged; it offers an emission-free, electric-only range of about 52 miles before the gasoline engine kicks in to power the vehicle in hybrid mode. The plug-in may be operated without charging as well, and can be driven in gas-electric hybrid mode exclusively.

Toyota says the new RAV4 will be the first of its product line to feature the newest version of the Toyota Auto Multimedia system, which offers “faster, more responsive voice assistant; a new customizable home menu; and Toyota's first application of onboard 5G connectivity.” Toyota had been criticized for earlier infotainment systems that excluded Apple CarPlay and Android systems; the automaker has since changed course and allowed its system to be more easily paired and synced with smartphones.

While Toyota builds a majority of its vehicles in North America, those imported from Canada and Mexico have been subject to the administration’s tariffs. The new RAV4 will be built primarily in Georgetown, Ky., and Cambridge, Ontario, with some models imported from Japan. Accordingly, Toyota in August said its operating profit for the fiscal year ended March 30 is estimated to be reduced to $21.7 billion, or 16.3%, from its prior forecast.

Toyota shares shrugged off the guidance, rising about 15% since then while outperforming major market indices.

Rising taxes

Nevertheless, tariffs remain a major stumbling block in front of earnings growth. Toyota has formulated a response, however, which was outlined earlier this month by Seeking Alpha analyst James Hires earlier this month. Bolstered by its vaunted financial strength, the automaker has elected to absorb a significant portion of the tariff burden by limiting price hikes that it otherwise might have taken. Last June, Toyota evidently increased prices by a smaller margin than those of competitors, thus improving its value proposition, which should help to drive sales.

Additionally, Toyota has told U.S. trade officials it is looking to export U.S.-made models to Japan, a move designed to “appease” the U.S. administration and help redress the trade deficit with Japan, which was about $70 billion in 2024.

At the Tokyo Mobility Show this week, the automaker took the wraps off a BEV concept of the next-gen Corolla compact sedan, the best-selling model in its history, with more than 55 million manufactured since the nameplate was introduced in 1966. The show car attracted rave reviews from journalists, one of whom said it was “seriously cool.” While it wasn’t clear when the production version of the Corolla would be introduced, Japanese carmakers usually don’t wait long after the concept is revealed.

Reports on the new Corolla say it will have more interior space, made possible by a new generation of engines that are more compact and powerful than current models. The model may accommodate batteries, hybrids, or possibly alternative fuels.

“The Corolla is a global car, so it has to meet different powertrain requirements in different regions,” Chief Engineer Toru Fukushima told Automotive News at a pre-show briefing.

Bullish on TM ADRs

My bullish investment thesis is based on a number of core factors, some of which are reflected in the new RAV4. First of all is operating discipline, which reflects a relentless pursuit of researching those traits and features in a vehicle that consumers prioritize and delivering them in an affordable package.

A second key factor is what has proven to be a shrewd strategic direction with regard to electrification, that's a gradual migration toward zero emission that currently emphasizes gas-electric hybrid powertrains—exemplified by the decision to offer the latest RAV4 as an all-hybrid product. Since the 1990s, when the first gas-electric hybrid was introduced in Toyota Prius, the company has been improving, tweaking, and optimizing its Hybrid Synergy Drive, while many of its competitors—now to their disadvantage—bypassed the technology or deemed it of secondary importance.

Additionally, the automaker’s policy of investing in the development of multiple propulsion pathways—such as plug-in hybrids, hydrogen, batteries, as well as internal combustion—enables Toyota to commercialize its models in a multitude of global markets and for different consumer groups.

Toyota’s strong financial position, the result of generations of conservative management, provides ample resources for future investment in cutting-edge technologies such as solid-state batteries and self-driving, as well as consistent dividend payments.

Two major risk factors to this investment thesis must be mentioned: The first is new and formidable competition from the Chinese auto industry, which increasingly demonstrates its mettle with Western consumers in foreign markets as well as China and could enter the U.S. at some future date, despite the current tariff roadblock.

Finally, Toyota faces the same risk as any automaker, that negative economic conditions will dampen demand for vehicles, thus undermining the growth of revenue and profit.

Toyota ADRs remain a buy in my judgment.

data.title: My Top 10 High-Yield Picks For November 2025: One Yields 9%+
data.description:
Investment Thesis

The investment approach of The Dividend Income Accelerator Portfolio and my personal portfolio is characterized by a focus on companies that pay sustainable dividends, have significant competitive advantages, and are financially robust.

Investing in dividend-paying companies with sustainable cash flows not only allows you to increase the dividend payments on an annual basis but also to invest with a margin of safety and to increase the probability of delivering positive investment outcomes when investing over the long term.

While some of the selected companies are particularly attractive due to their ability to provide an attractive amount of dividend income and to reduce portfolio volatility (such as Verizon (VZ), Altria (MO), and Ares Capital (ARCC)), some of the selected companies blend income with dividend growth (such as Münchener Rückversicherungs-Gesellschaft (OTCPK:MURGY), Principal Financial Group (NASDAQ:PFG), Iberdrola (OTCPK:IBDSF), Merck & Co (MRK), and Bank of Montreal (BMO)).

Companies such as Münchener Rückversicherungs-Gesellschaft, Iberdrola, and Bank of Montreal also help you increase the global diversification of your portfolio, which further reduces your portfolio's risk level.

The companies that have been selected for today's article needed to fulfill the below pre-requirements:

  • Market Capitalization > $10 billion
  • Dividend Yield [FWD] > 3%
  • 5-Year Dividend Growth Rate [CAGR] > 1.5%.
  • P/E [FWD] ratio < 30

For November 2025, I have selected the below high-yield dividend companies:

  • Münchener Rückversicherungs-Gesellschaft
  • Iberdrola
  • Merck & Co
  • CVS Health (CVS)
  • Chevron (CVX)
  • Verizon

Conclusion

The investment strategy of both The Dividend Income Accelerator Portfolio and my private investment portfolio is based on a strategic balance between dividend income and dividend growth: while the first has a stronger focus on dividend income, the second prioritizes dividend growth.

What all the selected companies have in common is their capacity to provide investors with sustainable dividend income, which not only allows investors to constantly raise their dividend income but also to increase the probability of delivering strong investment outcomes when investing over the long term.

This is the case because over the long term, the companies' stock prices will follow the earnings results of the respective companies. This is the reason why the investment horizon of my portfolios is over the long term and why I suggest investing in companies that pay sustainable dividend income and that have significant competitive advantages.
